item.title: Singleton Pattern
item.author: ssubbu
item.description:
A better way to implement Singleton Pattern : By passing a internal class to the Singleton class constructor, which is visible only to the Singleton class, we can make the constructor not to initialize the object. In simple, to prevent memory leakages, the constructor of the singleton should not run more than once.

Here is the solution:

package
{
  
    private static var instance:SingletonExample;
  
    public class SingletonExample
    {
      
        public function SingletonExample(singletonEnforcer:SingletonEnforcer)
        {
            //do nothing
        }
      
        public static function getInstance():DisplayManager
        {
            if(instance == null) {
                instance = new SingletonExample(new SingletonEnforcer());
            }
            return instance;
        }
      
    }
  
    class SingletonEnforcer{};  
      
  
}

Here, I am restricting the constructor not to instantiate any object on its own, by passing a internal class instance. This internal class will be visible only to the Singleton Class.

item.title: Simple use of Tree via XMLList and E4X
item.author: Ivascu Cristian
item.description:
External XML : Hi,
To get the XML data from an external file you need to add an URLLoader and populate the tree in the complete event handler (that's when the XML file has been completely read into a variable). The code should look like this(I have moved the entire XML into a separate file, called data.xml):

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<mx:Application   xmlns:mx="http://www.adobe.com/2006/mxml"
layout="absolute" creationComplete="loadDataTree()">
<mx:Script>
  <![CDATA[
   import mx.controls.Alert;
   import mx.rpc.events.ResultEvent;
   public function loadDataTree():void
   {
    var loader:URLLoader = new URLLoader(new URLRequest("data.xml"));
    loader.addEventListener("complete",setTree);
   }
   public function setTree(event:Event):void
   {
    var dataXML:XML = XML(event.target.data);
    treeView.dataProvider=dataXML;
    treeView.labelField = "@label";
   }
  ]]>
</mx:Script>
<mx:Tree id="treeView"  top="10"  left="10"  bottom="10"  right="10"  />
</mx:Application>

Cristian

item.title: A 3-state checkbox in a TreeItemRenderer
item.author: Mortimer Jazz
item.description:
errata : Great code. Here is a minor fix:
If you have a node with two or more children:
1) expand the node (without checking it)
2) check one of the children
3) uncheck the same child

The parent will remain in the 'schrodinger' state - this only happens on the initial run, and if your xml does not explicitly specify the 'state' attributes, as it results in noChecks=1, noUnChecks=0 and noCats=1, which will pass the first branch of the conditional.

To prevent this, change this line of getState method from :

if ((noChecks > 0 && noUnChecks > 0) || (noCats > 0))

to

if ((noChecks > 0 && noUnChecks > 0) || (noCats > 0 && noChecks>0))

item.title: Tracking results from multiple,simultaneous service calls
item.author: tyriker
item.description:
Great Info : This is great information I haven't been able to easily find elsewhere. Thanks for that!

Some additional information that helped me understand how this works. You can do something like:
private function run():void {
  var token:AsyncToken = service.send();
  token.resultHandler = result;
  token.anything = "anything";
}
private function result(e:ResultEvent):void {
  trace(e.token.anything);
}
and not worry about accessing e.token.anything in the result handler before it has actually been set. Even though service.send() is asynchronous, the execution of ActionScript is single threaded, and result handler of service can't actually happen until you're out of the current function. So you are free to safely add things to token, and not worry about the result handler triggering first. Hope this helps!

item.description:
Logging Out From Flex : Sorry as these comments may have gotten a touch off target, logging out of your flex app could use a little javascript and the Flex Ajax Bridge like so in an html wrapper:

<script src="bridge/FABridge.js" ></script>
<script type="text/javascript">
      
   function checkLogout()
   {
    var flexApp = FABridge.example.root();
    var loggedIn = flexApp.isLoggedIn();
    if(loggedIn)
    {
     flexApp.logoutUser();
     return "Please remember to logout before exiting.";
    }
        return;
   }
  
      window.onbeforeunload = checkLogout;
</script>

This would logout the user when trying to leave the page given isLoggedIn() is an actionscript function returning t/f and logoutUser() logs out theuser in your flex app.

item.title: I need a login/authentication component for Flex 2
item.author: nodirbek13
item.description:
no problem with PHP : Hi Mike,
Try as follows:
1.) IN FLEX: SEND the HTTPService data to your xxx.php script
2.) IN xxx.php: fetch the data ex:
$user = mysql_escape_string($_POST['user']);
$pass = mysql_escape_string($_POST['pass']);

3.) IN xxx.php perform the check agains DB or anything else. If the user is okay then return the XML with a loggedAs variable and the authorised users login as a value. Otherwise loggedAs='n/a'. Do not forget to create a php session and save the loggedAs ($_SESSION['loggedAs'] = $loggedUserName;)
example of the response XML:

<loginInfo>
<user>
        <loggedAs>n/a</loggedAs>
        <login>n/a</login>
</user>
</loginInfo>

4.) IN FLEX: Get the result back and see if loggedAs is 'n/a' or users name.
ex:
   function fn_getLoginResult():void{
    if (loginSender.lastResult.loginInfo.user.loggedAs =='n/a'){
    label1.text = 'Wrong login/password!';
    } else
    if (loginSender.lastResult.loginInfo.user.loggedAs !=''){
     currentState="user_page";      
    }

IMPORTANT!!!: in my case I always kept the sensitive data on the server, so before returning the data to the user, all server side scripts check if there is a session created. Otherwise return an XML with an alert/warning. This way, no matter how the user hacks the SWF file, if he is not autorized he will not get the data from the server.

Try using HTTP service to access the "browser's session scope" : The "trick" with most user log in sceneros is to use a "session" var to maintain scope.   Problem is you can't generate one from a webservice or remoting call,  you need to use a HTTP service call so the server will respond as if the call came from a web browser form.
Review this post for more details:
http://www.adobe.com/cfusion/communityengine/index.cfm?event=showdetails&postId=2001&productId=2

item.title: Sly as a Fox: Retrieving browser and server "State" information in Flex without AJAX or using the WRAPPER.
item.author: DannyZ
item.description:
Logging Out From Flex. : As far as I know, Handling a log out scenerio from flex when the user simply closes the browser window, would be fairly impossible to manage within FLEX  by itself.  Once you close the browser, Flex is no-longer running, thus it can not handle events.    
However, logout will automatically ocur. Coldfusion Session vars are defined with a timeout.  Once the timeout is reached the session var is ended, and the user's session scope is terminated, thereby logging out the user.      

Another common scenero is the user browsing away (but not closing the browser) from the page.    Here one could use javascript and flex or ajax to make a script call to a logout method.  

Logging out a session from within Flex ;  just as the session vars are present within the browser scope,  a logout from flex will also require a http service call to a logout method to kill the session vars.
